title: 109_hr2068
content: The "Meat Promotion Act of 2005" establishes a voluntary program for country of origin labeling for meat, including definitions for beef, lamb, pork, covered meat products, and the role of the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a voluntary program for country of origin labeling for covered meat products. The program will include designing a label to designate the country of origin and limiting the use of the United States as a country of origin. The program established under section 292 limits the designation of a covered meat product as having the United States as the country of origin to products derived exclusively from animals born, raised, and slaughtered in the United States, or born and raised in Alaska or Hawaii and slaughtered in the United States. Participants may be required to maintain records for verification of compliance, and enforcement measures are in place. SEC. 296 outlines the enforcement of civil penalties for violations of the program established under section 292, with a maximum penalty of $10,000 per violation. Each day of violation is considered a separate offense. A notice and hearing are required before penalties are assessed. SEC. 297 pertains to regulations. "Within 180 days of the Meat Promotion Act of 2005, the Secretary must create regulations for the program under section 292. Subtitle D of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 is amended to include Country of Origin Labeling for Fish, Perishable Agricultural Commodities, and Peanuts." In section 281, paragraphs (1), (5), and (7) are removed, and in paragraph (2)(A), clauses (i) and (ii) are struck. Paragraphs (2), (3), (4), (6), (8), and (9) are redesignated as paragraphs (1), (2), (3), (4), (5), and (6) respectively. In section 282, subparagraphs (A) and (B) are removed from subsection (a)(2) and redesignated as subparagraphs (A), (B), and (C) respectively. In subsection (f)(2), subparagraphs (A), (B), and (C) are removed and subparagraphs (D) and (E) are redesignated as subparagraphs (A) and (B).
